bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, October 31, 1939

div1.p: Kean discusses a future meeting with Hench, his relationship with Reed, and his experiences with the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, October 31, 1939
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Oct. 31st 1939
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn-
My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
Your letter of the 27th gave me
great pleasure- I should be greatly
pleased to meet you wherever you
may come to Washington and to talk
over with you the details of the dra-
matic episode of Walter Reed and
the conquest of Yellow Fever-

Reed and I were good friends before
the Yellow Fever Board came to Cuba
in June 1900 and he located himself
at Marianao, 8 miles S. W. of Havana,
largely I think because it was
the Hdqrs of the Dept. of Havana Province and
Ac
K
2
Penar del Rio and I was the Chief
Surgeon of that Dept. and so would
be able to give him administrative
assistance- It was also considered
a safer place to locate as regards
yellow fever, but as to this he may
have had some doubts, when on arrival
he found me in the quarantined camp
hospital sick with yellow fever-!
I was quite an courant with his work
as it proceeded step by step and
therefore will be able to make many
points clear to you which may not
be so at present- I would be very
glad to have a list of questions as
you propose, which I could look
up in my rather volumicious files
and so be prepared to answer them
when I see you- But I cannot
3
promise anything in the way of
collaboration in the preparation
of articles further than to be a
reservoir of source material-

I have no clerk on office assis-
tance, having been retired for 15
years and in my eightieth year
of age- So all my correspondence
has to be in long hand as I
never learned to use the typewriter
myself - having been spoiled by having
clerical assistance provided for
me during many years of active
service.

The city of Havana, was itself a
separate Dept. from the Province of
Havana and Gorgas was its Chief
Surgeon from 1899 to 1902 when the
4
Republic of Cuba came into being.
He and I were good friends and
often saw each other, though our
spheres of activity and administration
authority were quite distinct-

I knew Moran and Kissinger well
I find in my diary that on ‘New Years’
Day 1901 I went to see Moran at the hospi-
tal and found him doing finely with
temperature normal- A week decides
the fate of yellow fever patients-

I shall be very pleased to see
you whenever you come to Washington-
I hope however you may not by chance
come in the next two weeks as I go
tomorrow to Boston for a little visit-
